.N - what you described as "high class" parents is exactly like many parents in my upper middle class suburb here in western WA. About half the moms don't work but nearly all are college educated, some had very successful professional careers before becoming stay-at-home moms. These are moms who are the most active in the PTA and volunteer a lot in classrooms. Whether or not they work outside the home, most of the moms are close to their children and care about their education and general well being. Are there still bratty kids and kids who just don't do well even with parents who actively volunteer? Sure. Kids will be kids, and abilities vary. But I believe most people will consider this a good school district.

Nita - what you experienced sound like parents in NYC or certain very affluent zip codes.

I believe you are both right. There are parents who handover care of children to nannies(even when moms don't work), overschedule their kids to death and expect them to achieve to satisfy their own ego, but I believe these are the minority(though it may seem like the majority in certain areas). I believe the majority of parents in the country, esp. in upper middle class suburbs, are like those .N describe, parents who are highly involved in their children's life out of genuine care and love.

provide all schools with equal amounts of money and equipment, and let the good teachers in poor districts stay put with pay equal to other districts. in other words take the racism out of the equation.

You should live in Texas where racism is rampant. The schools in my affluent schools district are lovely, state of the art schools. But somehow the district has divided the district so the Hispanic and Afro American children are all at the same schools. It was amazing to me that what I was seeing was really segregation. This is explained that all the Spanish speaking students live in the areas around the older schools and that there is a good mix of Afro American students included, so it is not really segregation.

But in reality, racism is evident in everyday talk among neighbors and it includes comments about anyone who is different. When I was playing a game with a group of seniors, I heard a lady comment about the "cotton-pickers". I spoke up and asked who she was referring to and she said the "n" word.
I am from the north and have live in Texas for 50 years and have seen no progress in attitudes here. Also the churches seem to invite all to contribute to the coffers, but "different" people are still frowned upon. How can you be a Christian and a bigot too? We have a long way to go in race relations and it won't happen in the years I have left.

This is like deja vu, similar stories are being played out over and over again across many school districts around the country, mostly near major cities. The problem cannot be fixed as long as we continue to use the term "Bad Schools". "Schools" cannot be bad, schools are just buildings with desks and chairs. Neither are the teachers or administrators the biggest problems, they are just easy scapegoats. The biggest problem is the students themselves. These are not innocent victims. Victims do not bring guns to school, sell drugs, threaten, assault, beat up and shoot at other students or teachers. These are downright criminals. We need to start using the term Bad Students, then we will realize that busing these bad students everywhere will just spread the problem everywhere. Send the criminals to jail or juvenile delinquent facilities depending on the severity of crime, and allow the ones who came to learn, learn.

Read the book "Bad Students, Not Bad Schools" by Robert Weissberg. Spot on.
I'm sad to say that this is pretty predictable.  School choice programs have stirred up these sorts of tensions before.
How  about Normandy hiring the most recently retired elementary principal, curriculum specialist, or two from any more successful district nearby to come there to help them learn to succeed?

1. Normandy spent $12,276 on avg per pupil last school year. Francis Howell spent $9,830. Missouri has a state law that requires every district provide a minimum funding per student with the shortfall in local property taxes made up by state funds. Normandy students will join a district that spends less per pupil than their home district.
2. Last year's MAP (Missouri Assessment for Performance) results show 20-30% of students in all grades in Normandy are proficient/advanced in math/literacy/science. The same rates are 60-70% in Francis Howell.
3. In Normandy 12.4% of the students in all grades were suspended/disciplined for > 10 days last school year. That's 1 in 10 students across all grades. That same stat in Francis Howell is 1.6%. 1 in 100 students face the same discipline as in Normandy. Doesn't that take your breath away? This is discipline for major issues - weapons, drugs, assaults.
4. The real elephant in the room is why the NY Times reporter did not present these numbers in the article. Wouldn't this have provided a more nuanced view of the challenges in this difficult situation? These facts are all available on the Missouri Dept of Education dese.mo.gov.

My children attend a different suburban St Louis district with 20% deseg students plus another 5% expected from this program. The diversity these students bring are greatly appreciated by the parents who pay extra taxes to cover the shortfall of the VICC program. We will welcome these new students!

I live in FHSD and quite frankly and NOT happy with the transfer. We pay a crazy amount in taxes that goes to our school so that our kids get a good education. It isn't about Normandy not having enough money to make their district better. If they paid their staff what other districts pay they would have the money to provide education to their children. The MO average teacher salary is $45,709 and in Normandy it is $61,083. Administration MO average is $84,791 and Normandy is $105,425. The gym at Normandy high looks like a pro athlete gym . Normandy's priorities have never been the education of it's students but what shiny things can they have.

At our meeting we had families that stood up that moved from that area out to our district to get away from all of that say they don't want the Normandy kids out here.
.
If those families want a better school move to a better district... it is just that simple. There are plenty of housing opportunities in all the neighboring school districts. The fact of the matter is the Normandy residents don't want to leave their comfort areas.

Is this about race... sort of . on both sides of the fence. The "Black" families don't want their kids going to school with our children that according to the article are " going to stand on the front steps with hoses and not let them off the bus" and our families that don't want the crime that the #1 most dangerous school in St. Louis has brought to our community.

As a mom of 3 children in the Francis Howell School District, I wish the media would stop mischaracterizing this situation as one of race. It is NOT racially motivated.

The announcement made at the meeting where people were upset was unclear on how many students would be transferring, and what the impacts would be for the children. If all 4500 Normandy students would have transferred, the parent's concerns would have been valid, regardless of the race of the children. According to the FHSD website, our school only has 400-600 additional student capacity. So, now that we know that 416 children are transferring, many of the parents concerns have been solved.

Schedule pickup for middle school was today, and, at our school, there were NO ISSUES. So, will there be a follow-up article stating that all went well? Probably not.

For those commenting that race issues are not getting better, be aware, they are improving. I have many black neighbors, and we get along well. They are concerned that their kids will be labeled "sell-outs" because most of their friends are white and the parents are financially successful.

We need to stop referring to ourselves as white Americans or African-Americans (an impossibility to be so, since one would have to have citizenship in Africa and America).

We are ALL AMERICANS, and the education of ALL American children should be our goal. I, for one, am happy to see more diversity happening so we can learn from each other.

Excellent explanation, Mr. Boeckenstadt, of the broad criteria used for selecting applicants at many elite universities for quite some time. More than three decades ago I served for several years on the Yale Undergraduate Admissions Committee. What made it very different from UC today was not the variety of criteria employed--we too looked at a wide range factors--but who was employing it. Instead of 70 outside readers, contracted to review 53,000 applications, and spending an average of 8 minutes per application, Yale used a large team of its own professors to read nearly 10,000 applications. Not only did each of us spent a great deal of time with each application (carefully reading letters of recommendation, student essays, etc.) but we then met in teams with the Dean of Admissions and various specialists to discuss--sometimes briefly, sometimes at great length--and to vote by secret ballot on each and every applicant.

I don't know if Yale still does things this way. But while it was very labor intensive work by uncompensated professors, it worked. The UC faculty is certainly large enough to do the same thing--if they are so inclined.
